title: Snoop Dogg responds to backlash over his risque University of Kansas performance
text:
Snoop Dogg has responded to the controversy he has brewed up after performing explicit versions of his famous hits, alongside pole dancers, at the University of Kansas on Friday.

The 30 minute performance received criticism online and forced the school to issue an apology.

During his visit to the Howard Stern Show on Tuesday, he brushed off the haters and said the school did nothing wrong.

What's the hype? Snoop Dogg brushed off the haters and said the school did nothing wrong. during his visit to the Howard Stern Show on Tuesday, following a controversial performance

'The audience enjoyed that s***,' the 47-year-old said. 'I don't know what the f*** they talking about.'

Snoop (born Calvin Cordozar Broadus Jr.) went on to insist that he had a great experience and that backlash forced the school to respond.

He said: 'And, when you pay for Snoop Dogg, you gon get Snoop Dogg.'

'I think it was more the publicity of what I did. they had to cover it up,' he said. 'And, I respect them, and I wasn't gonna put no smut on their name and say they did anything wrong because they invited me to come do what I do.'

What happened: He performed explicit versions of his famous hits, alongside pole dancers, at the University of Kansas on Friday

Dancer drama: Female dancers performed on poles that were moved to the court and had fake $100 bills raining on them

But when asked by the radio show host if the reports that he was asked to leave afterwards are true, the Gin and Juice rapper said it was a not true.

'That's a motherf***ing lie. I had the time of my life.' he said. 'I enjoyed myself, hung out with the basketball teams.

After his performance the Athletic Director at KU, Jeff Long, took responsibility for the less than family friendly performance, and mentioned the school told managers they hoped for a g-rated performance.

It's what I do: He said: 'And, when you pay for Snoop Dogg, you gon get Snoop Dogg'

'I take full responsibility for not thoroughly vetting all details of the performance,' Long said. 'And offer my personal apology to those who were offended.'

He added: 'We strive to create a family atmosphere at Kansas and fell short of that this evening.'

While some were angered by the performance online, others found it to be expected of the rapper, as did the KU students.

'We all know how Snoop gets down, so we expected it,' one student said to Fox4KC.
